instruction: If a customer inquires about purchasing insurance and states they are not a US resident, do not ask which US state they will visit. Instead, inform them that Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
input: Hi, I need help purchasing travel insurance. I‚Äôm not a US resident, I‚Äôm from Queensland. Can I buy Faye insurance for my trip?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Faye insurance is only available to US residents of all states, except for residents of the following US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you reaching out, and I'm happy to help clarify our coverage areas for you.

Unfortunately, Faye insurance is only available to US residents. Since you're located in Queensland, Australia, you wouldn't be eligible for Faye coverage at this time.

That said, I want to make sure you have all the details: Faye insurance is available to residents across all US states, with the exception of the following US territories:
- United States Virgin Islands
- Northern Mariana Islands
- Guam
- American Samoa
- Puerto Rico

I'm sorry we can't assist with your travel insurance needs on this occasion. If you have any other questions or if there's anything else I can help you with, please don't hesitate to reach out. Safe travels! ‚úàÔ∏è
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. When informed the customer is not a US resident (specifically from Queensland, Australia), the agent did not ask which US state they would visit. Instead, the agent provided the required information about Faye insurance availability, listing all US states as eligible except for the five specified US territories: United States Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico.

While the agent's response is more verbose and has a different tone than the expected answer (more conversational and empathetic), the core logic and required information are present and accurate. The agent also appropriately explained why the customer isn't eligible, which provides helpful context without violating the instruction.

instruction: If you identify that any modifications are required to an existing policy, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate authority or supervisor for review and approval before proceeding with any changes.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. I bought a policy and noticed there's a typo in my last name. I need you to change it.
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know! Since this involves a modification to an existing policy, I‚Äôll need to escalate your request to the appropriate authority for review and approval before any changes can be made. I‚Äôll pass this along right away.
agent_answer:
I completely understand how important it is to have your information accurate on your policy‚Äîthat's definitely something we want to get sorted out for you right away! 

I'll need to escalate your request to review and approve this name correction. This ensures that the modification is handled properly and securely on your account. A human agent from our team will reach out to you shortly to:

‚Ä¢ Verify your identity and policy details
‚Ä¢ Confirm the correct spelling of your last name
‚Ä¢ Process the correction for you

You should expect to hear from them soon. In the meantime, if you have any other questions or information you'd like to provide, feel free to share it here and I'll make sure it's included with your escalation.

Thank you for your patience! üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to escalate the policy modification request. While the tone and presentation differ from the expected answer (being more detailed and reassuring), the core logic is aligned:

1. The agent clearly identifies that a modification to an existing policy is required (name correction on policy)
2. The agent explicitly states "I'll need to escalate your request to review and approve this name correction"
3. The agent indicates that a human agent will handle the escalation and reach out
4. The agent confirms that the modification will be handled properly before proceeding

The agent's response contains additional helpful information (what the human agent will do, timeline expectations) beyond the expected answer, but this adds value without contradicting the instruction. The escalation intent is clear and unmistakable, satisfying the critical rule requirement.

instruction: If a customer continues to experience issues with any part of the quoting process after receiving one troubleshooting message, immediately escalate the issue to the appropriate support team.
input: Hi, I'm from MO. Your quote link is broken, and the troubleshooting you sent me doesn't work. What do I do?
expected_answer: I'm sorry you're still having trouble with the quote process. Since the issue persists after troubleshooting, I'll escalate this to our support team right away so they can assist you further.
agent_answer:
I'm sorry to hear you're still having trouble with the quoting process‚ÄîI know how frustrating that can be. I really appreciate your patience while we've worked through the troubleshooting steps together.

Since you're continuing to experience issues even after trying those suggestions, I think it's time to get you some extra support. I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can take a deeper look at what's happening with your quote link and find a solution that works for you.

A team member will be reaching out to you shortly to assist. Thank you for sticking with us, and we'll get this sorted out for you! üòä
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to escalate the issue after the customer continued to experience problems with the quoting process. The agent clearly communicated the escalation through multiple phrases ("I'm going to escalate your request to one of our human agents", "A team member will be reaching out to you shortly"), which satisfies the critical rule for escalation language.

While the agent's tone and length differ from the expected answer (more empathetic and detailed), the core logic is identical: acknowledging the persistent issue and immediately escalating to the appropriate support team. The agent also provided additional helpful context about what the support team will do, which adds value without contradicting the instruction.

The response fully aligns with the instruction's requirement to escalate when issues persist after troubleshooting.

instruction: If you determine that travelers reside in different states, always inform them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together. Advise them that if they live in different states, they must purchase separate policies, even if their question was about a different topic.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. I want to buy coverage for my family trip. We are 4 ‚Äî I'm Bobby Lee and my wife Andrew Santino are flying from CA to Mexico, and our daughter Rudy Jules is flying from Texas. We fly from 25/12/25 to 25/01/26. How much would it cost?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! Since some travelers live in different states, you won‚Äôt be able to purchase a single policy together. All travelers must reside in the same state to be on one policy. Because your daughter lives in Texas while you and your wife live in California, you‚Äôll need to purchase separate policies for each state. I‚Äôm happy to help guide you through each one.
agent_answer:
Hi Bobby! Thanks for sharing those details about your family trip to Mexico. I appreciate you letting me know about your travel plans.

I want to make sure you have the right coverage for everyone. Here's what I need to let you know:

**All travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together.** Since your daughter Rudy Jules is flying from Texas while you and Andrew are in California, you'll need to purchase separate policies for her.

So here's how it would work:
- One policy for you and Andrew (both from California)
- A separate policy for Rudy Jules (from Texas)

I know that's an extra step, but this ensures everyone gets the right coverage for your trip! If you'd like to move forward, I'm happy to help you get quotes for both policies. üòä
reason:
The agent correctly followed the instruction by identifying that travelers reside in different states (Texas vs California) and explicitly informing them that all travelers must live in the same state to purchase a policy together. The agent advised them to purchase separate policies for each state.

While the agent's tone is slightly more conversational and includes additional helpful details (like emojis and offering to help with quotes), the core logic matches the expected answer. Both responses:
1. Identify the multi-state residency issue
2. State the requirement that all travelers must live in the same state
3. Clearly explain they need separate policies
4. Specify which travelers go in which policy

The agent provided more context and a friendlier tone, but did not go against the instruction or deviate from the core message. This falls under the "pass" criteria where the agent answer has more information but the core logic is close enough.

instruction: When a customer asks about travel to a U.S. Department of State Level 4 ("Do Not Travel") destination, state that coverage is unavailable and do not list any benefits. This applies regardless of state of residence.
input: Hi, I'm from TX. I want to visit my family in Afghanistan. I believe it's a Level 4 country. How much will it cost? Will it cost extra because of it?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage is unavailable for travel to any U.S. Department of State Level 4 (‚ÄúDo Not Travel‚Äù) destination, including Afghanistan. We‚Äôre unable to offer a policy for this trip.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you reaching out, and I understand how important it is to visit family. I do want to let you know that **coverage is unavailable for travel to this destination**.

Unfortunately, we're unable to provide coverage for Afghanistan at this time. I know that's not the answer you were hoping for, and I'm sorry we can't help with this particular trip.

If you have any questions about this or would like to explore coverage options for other destinations, I'm here to help. üòä
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly by stating that coverage is unavailable for travel to Afghanistan (a Level 4 "Do Not Travel" destination) and did not list any benefits. 

While the tone is slightly different and more empathetic than the expected answer, the fundamental requirement is met. The agent:
1. Clearly states coverage is unavailable for the destination
2. Does not list any benefits
3. Applies this regardless of other circumstances

The agent's additional empathetic language and offer to help with other destinations does not violate the instruction and is a reasonable extension that maintains customer service while adhering to the core requirement.

instruction: If the customer is from Washington (WA) or Missouri (MO), inform them that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state.
input: Hi, I'm from Washington, and I want to do extreme white-water rafting in Skykomish. How much for adding this coverage?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! The Adventure Sports add-on is not available for residents of Washington, so unfortunately it can‚Äôt be added to your policy.
agent_answer: I'm sorry, but the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in your state. I know that's disappointing, especially when you have an exciting trip like white-water rafting in Skykomish planned! If you'd like, I'm happy to explore other coverage options that might work for you, or you can reach out to our team to see if there are any alternatives available.
reason: The agent followed the core instruction correctly by informing the customer that the Adventure Sports add-on is not available in their state (Washington). While the agent's tone and delivery differ from the expected answer‚Äîbeing more conversational and offering alternative solutions‚Äîthe fundamental requirement is met. The agent clearly communicated the unavailability of the Adventure Sports add-on, which is the critical instruction. The additional information about exploring other coverage options goes beyond the expected answer but doesn't contradict or violate the instruction.

instruction: Currently, Faye does not offer an annual plan as we've determined that we can provide the most value with coverage for individual trips.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. Look, I fly a lot and it's really frustrating to buy a coverage policy each time. Can you do an annual plan for me?
expected_answer: I hear you ‚Äî frequent travel can make this process feel repetitive. At the moment, Faye does not offer an annual plan, as we‚Äôve found we can provide the most value through coverage for individual trips. I'm happy to help you with a new trip policy anytime you need one.
agent_answer:
I totally understand your frustration‚Äîconstantly purchasing coverage for each trip can definitely feel like a hassle, especially when you're flying frequently! 

Here's the thing: we've found that our trip-by-trip coverage model actually allows us to deliver the most value to our customers. Rather than a yearly plan, this approach means you get tailored protection for each specific journey.

The good news? Getting a quote for your upcoming trips is super straightforward. Just head over to www.withfaye.com/quote/destination, and you'll be able to lock in coverage quickly and easily.

Is there a particular trip coming up that I can help you get covered for? üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. The core logic is maintained: the agent clearly states that Faye does not offer an annual plan and explains that the trip-by-trip coverage model allows them to provide the most value to customers.

While the tone and presentation differ from the expected answer (the agent is more conversational and enthusiastic, and includes additional details like a direct link to get a quote), these differences align with the "When To Pass" criteria. The agent's answer contains more information than expected but maintains the core message. The agent also offers to help with future trips, which is consistent with the spirit of the expected answer.

The instruction is not violated, and the essential information is communicated clearly.

instruction: When responding to a customer who has lost their mobile phone, express genuine empathy by acknowledging their frustration and concern. Use a warm and understanding tone, and offer reassurance that you are there to help them through the process of resolving the issue.
input: Hi, I'm from FL and I just lost my mobile phone while traveling. I'm really stressed ‚Äî what should I do?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm so sorry to hear that you lost your phone ‚Äî that‚Äôs incredibly frustrating, especially while traveling. I‚Äôm here to help you through this. Let‚Äôs work together to figure out the next steps so you can get this resolved as quickly as possible.
agent_answer: I'm so sorry to hear that you've lost your mobile phone. I can only imagine how frustrating and concerning this must be for you right now, especially while you're traveling away from home. Please know that I'm here to help you through this process and we'll work together to resolve this issue. What would you like to do next?
reason:
The agent successfully followed the instruction to express genuine empathy, acknowledge frustration and concern, use a warm and understanding tone, and offer reassurance. While the agent's output is longer and more detailed than the expected answer, it covers all the core elements:

1. Expresses empathy ("I'm so sorry to hear that you've lost your mobile phone")
2. Acknowledges frustration and concern ("I can only imagine how frustrating and concerning this must be for you right now")
3. Shows understanding by referencing their context ("especially while you're traveling away from home")
4. Offers reassurance of help ("Please know that I'm here to help you through this process")
5. Commits to working together ("we'll work together to resolve this issue")
6. Uses a warm and understanding tone throughout

The agent answer exceeds the expected answer by asking what the customer would like to do next, which is helpful and appropriate. The core logic and instruction adherence are essentially identical, making this a passing response.

instruction: If a customer is asking for an update or status of a claim that has already been filed, they can see the status of the claim in the Faye app, or email the claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi Im from CA, I have a claim, and it been some time since I sent it, can you tell me what its status?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out! You can check the status of your claim directly in the Faye app. If you‚Äôd like more details or have specific questions, you can also email our claims team at claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer:
I'd be happy to help you check on that! Here are the best ways to get an update on your claim status:

You can check the status of your claim in the Faye app, or email the claims team directly at claims@withfaye.com for an update.

The team there will be able to give you the most current information about where things stand with your claim. I know waiting can be frustrating, so hopefully you'll get some clarity soon! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses cover the core logic:
1. Direct the customer to check the status in the Faye app
2. Provide the email address (claims@withfaye.com) as an alternative

While the agent's tone is slightly warmer and more conversational (with additional empathetic statements like "I know waiting can be frustrating"), this doesn't go against the instruction. The agent actually provides more helpful context by explaining that the claims team will provide the most current information, which adds value without contradicting the instruction. All critical information from the expected answer is present in the agent's response.

instruction: The Faye app is available only on phones (Apple/Android). If a person does not want to download the app or wants to view the claim/send info about the claim on their computer, they can send an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi I'm from AZ, I want to send some papers about my claim, and I don't have a smart phone, what do I do?
expected_answer: No worries at all ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt have a smartphone, you can still manage your claim. You can email any documents or information directly to our claims team at claims@withfaye.com, and they‚Äôll take care of it for you.
agent_answer: Great question! I'm glad you reached out. You have a couple of convenient options for filing your claim, even without a smartphone. You can file a claim using the Faye app or by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com. Since you don't have a smartphone, the email option would work perfectly for you‚Äîjust send your claim documents directly to that address, and our team will take care of it from there. We're here to help make this as easy as possible for you! üòä
reason:
The agent's answer follows the instruction correctly and conveys the core message of the expected answer. Both responses communicate that:
1. The Faye app is available on phones
2. Without a smartphone, the user can email claims@withfaye.com
3. The claims team will handle the documents/information

While the agent's answer is longer and has a slightly different tone (more enthusiastic with "Great question!" and an emoji), the core logic is aligned with the instruction. The agent provides the correct alternative solution (email to claims@withfaye.com) for users without smartphones, which is the essential requirement. The additional context about "filing your claim" and reassurance that "we're here to help" add value without contradicting the instruction.

instruction: When a customer asks about how to file a claim or the claim process, instruct them to file a claim using the Faye app or by sending an email to claims@withfaye.com.
input: Hi, I'm from NY. My luggage was lost on my last trip and I want to file a claim. How do I start the claim process?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear about your lost luggage. To file a claim or follow the claim process, you can submit it directly through the Faye app, or send an email with your details and any supporting documents to claims@withfaye.com.
agent_answer:
I'm sorry to hear about your lost luggage‚ÄîI know how frustrating that can be! üòü

The good news is that filing a claim is straightforward. You have two convenient options:

1. **File through the Faye app** ‚Äì this is quick and easy if you have it handy
2. **Send an email to claims@withfaye.com** ‚Äì just include the details about your lost luggage

Either way, our team will be ready to help you get this sorted out. Let me know if you need any other assistance!
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer very close to the expected one. Both responses:
1. Acknowledge the customer's situation (lost luggage)
2. Instruct them to file a claim using the Faye app
3. Provide the email address claims@withfaye.com as an alternative method

While the agent's tone is more conversational and empathetic with additional supportive language ("I know how frustrating that can be!", "quick and easy", "our team will be ready to help"), the core logic and essential information match the expected answer. The agent also formats the two options more clearly with numbering, which enhances clarity without deviating from the instruction. This is consistent with the "When To Pass" criteria that allows for different tone and additional helpful information as long as the core logic is close enough.

instruction: ALWAYS share the link https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation with customers.
input: Hi, I'm from GA. I'm thinking of canceling my upcoming trip because of a family emergency. What are the covered reasons for trip cancellation?
expected_answer: I‚Äôm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency. You can review all covered reasons for trip cancellation here: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/. This page explains when you may be eligible for reimbursement.
agent_answer:
I'm sorry to hear you're dealing with a family emergency‚Äîthat sounds stressful, and I'm glad you're exploring your options. Trip cancellation coverage can really help in situations like this.

The good news is that many travel insurance plans do cover trip cancellations due to family emergencies, but the specific reasons covered can vary by policy. To give you the most accurate information about what qualifies, I'd recommend checking out this helpful resource: https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/

It breaks down the common covered reasons for trip cancellation, which should help you understand whether your situation would be eligible for coverage under your policy. If after reviewing that you have questions about your specific coverage or need clarification on anything, I'm here to help! üíô
reason: The agent successfully followed the instruction by sharing the required link https://blog.withfaye.com/travel-insurance-101/covered-reasons-for-trip-cancellation/ when discussing covered reasons for trip cancellation. While the agent's response is more detailed and has a warmer, more conversational tone compared to the expected answer, the core logic is aligned. Both responses acknowledge the family emergency situation, direct the customer to the specific link about covered reasons for trip cancellation, and offer further assistance. The agent's additional context about policy variations and empathetic language enhances the response without contradicting the instruction or expected answer.

instruction: The policy is emailed to the customer immediately upon purchasing. They can also view the policy in the Faye app. If this is mentioned to them and they say they have not received this, escalate.
input: Hi, I'm from NV. I paid for a policy and got a confirmation message on the website, but I never got the policy in the app or by email. What do I do?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know. Since the policy is emailed immediately after purchase and should also appear in the app, and you haven‚Äôt received it in either place, I‚Äôll escalate this right away so the team can look into it for you.
agent_answer:
I completely understand how frustrating that must be, especially after completing your purchase! It's great that you received the confirmation on the website, but I can see why you'd be concerned about not finding the policy in the app or email yet.

Since you've already checked both places and the policy still isn't showing up, I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents who can look into your account directly and figure out what's going on. They'll have the ability to investigate the delivery issue and make sure you get your policy information right away.

A team member will be with you shortly to help sort this out. Thanks for your patience! üòä
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly. The core logic is aligned with the expected answer:

1. The agent acknowledged that the policy should be emailed immediately after purchase and available in the app (matching the instruction).
2. The agent confirmed the customer hasn't received it in either place (the trigger for escalation).
3. The agent explicitly escalated the issue by stating "I'll need to escalate your request to one of our human agents" (meets the Critical Rule #1 for escalation language).

While the tone and phrasing differ from the expected answer (more empathetic and detailed), the core logic is close enough. The agent provided additional context and reassurance, which doesn't go against the instruction and makes the response more helpful. The key instruction requirement‚Äîto escalate when a customer says they haven't received the policy‚Äîwas properly executed.

instruction:
When customers reach out asking Faye's contact information.

Customers can always chat with us in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com or call us at 1-833-240-7056 (US/Canada). From all other locations, call us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. Can you give me Faye‚Äôs contact information?
expected_answer: Of course! You can always chat with us directly in the Faye app, email us at support@withfaye.com, or call us at 1-833-240-7056 from the US or Canada. If you're traveling internationally, you can reach us at 1-804-482-2122. We're available 24/7 and here to help.
agent_answer:
Here are the ways to reach our customer support team:

**Chat with us in the Faye app**

**Email:** support@withfaye.com

**Phone (US/Canada):** +1 833-240-7056

**Phone (all other locations):** +1 804-482-2122

We're available 24/7.

I can also transfer you to a live agent right now if you'd like to speak with someone directly. Would you like me to do that?
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided all the required contact information. The answer includes:
1. Chat option in the Faye app ‚úì
2. Email address (support@withfaye.com) ‚úì
3. US/Canada phone number (1-833-240-7056) ‚úì
4. International phone number (1-804-482-2122) ‚úì
5. 24/7 availability mention ‚úì

While the format differs from the expected answer (using a structured list instead of prose), the core logic and all critical information are present and accurate. The agent actually provided more helpful formatting with clear headers. The additional offer to transfer to a live agent goes beyond the instruction but doesn't contradict it. All key contact methods and availability information match the instruction requirements.

instruction: Customers experiencing a medical situation while traveling may visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice. There is no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers; all licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable.
input: Hi, I'm from MT. If I will feel sick while traveling, do I need to go to a specific clinic that works with you, or can I see any doctor?
expected_answer: If you ever feel sick while traveling, you can visit any doctor or medical facility of your choice. There‚Äôs no requirement to use an in-network or affiliated provider ‚Äî any licensed medical professional or facility is perfectly acceptable.
agent_answer:
Great question! I'm glad you asked about this before your travels. Here's the good news: if you experience a medical situation while you're traveling, you have complete flexibility in choosing where to receive care.

You can visit **any doctor or medical facility of your choice** ‚Äî there's no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers. All licensed medical professionals and facilities are completely acceptable, so you can feel confident seeking care wherever is most convenient for you during your trip.

This means you can focus on getting the care you need without worrying about provider restrictions. Safe travels! üòä
reason:
The agent's answer successfully conveys the core instruction: customers can visit any doctor or medical facility of their choice while traveling, with no requirement to use in-network or affiliated providers, and all licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable.

While the agent's tone is more conversational and enthusiastic compared to the expected answer (which is more straightforward), the core logic and information are aligned. The agent actually reinforces the message with additional reassurance ("you have complete flexibility," "feel confident," "focus on getting the care you need"), which enhances rather than contradicts the instruction.

All key elements from the instruction are present:
- Can visit any doctor or medical facility of choice
- No requirement for in-network or affiliated providers
- All licensed medical professionals and facilities are acceptable

The slight differences in wording and tone do not deviate from the instruction or contradict its intent.

instruction: If someone would like to print the policy, they can do so from the PDF that is emailed immediately after purchase.
input: Hi, I'm from OR. I want to print my policy ‚Äî how can I do that?
expected_answer: You can print your policy from the PDF that‚Äôs emailed to you immediately after purchase. Just open the PDF from your email and print it whenever you need.
agent_answer: Great question! You can print your policy from the PDF that's emailed to you right away after your purchase. Just look for that email in your inbox, and you'll be all set! üìß
reason:
The agent followed the instruction correctly and provided an answer that is close enough to the expected one. Both responses convey the same core message: customers can print their policy from a PDF that is emailed to them after purchase. 

While the agent's tone is slightly more conversational and includes an emoji (which differs from the expected answer's tone), the core logic is identical. The agent includes all essential information from the instruction: (1) printing is possible, (2) it's from a PDF, (3) the PDF is emailed, (4) this happens immediately/right away after purchase. The agent even adds helpful guidance about checking the inbox, which enhances clarity without contradicting the instruction.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) check if the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi Im from AL there is a bug in the website I get a 404. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for letting me know about the issue. First, what browser you're using to access the website?
agent_answer: What browser are you using to access the website where you're experiencing the 404 error?
reason: The agent followed the first step of the instruction correctly by asking about the browser being used to access the website. While the agent's wording is slightly different from the expected answer ("What browser are you using to access the website where you're experiencing the 404 error?" vs "Thanks for letting us know about the issue. First, what browser you're using to access the website?"), the core logic is the same - the agent is initiating step 1 of the troubleshooting process by asking about the browser. The agent's answer contains additional context (mentioning the 404 error), which is acceptable per the evaluation criteria. The agent is following the correct sequence of instructions starting with the browser check.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for the details and for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome. Next, can you please check that you have a strong and stable Wi-Fi connection, and then try again?
agent_answer: Is your WiFi connection working properly? I want to rule out connectivity issues since you're experiencing a 404 error on the website.
reason: The agent's response follows the core logic of the instruction's step 2, which is to ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. While the agent doesn't explicitly confirm the user is using Chrome (step 1), the response directly addresses connectivity issues by asking about WiFi connection quality, which matches the expected answer's intent. The agent's wording is different from the expected answer ("Is your WiFi connection working properly?" vs "can you please check that you have a strong and stable Wi-Fi connection"), but the core instruction‚Äîchecking for a strong Wi-Fi connection‚Äîis present. The agent didn't prematurely escalate, which aligns with the instruction to only escalate if the issue persists after these checks. The agent's approach is close enough to the expected answer in terms of core logic and instruction adherence.

instruction: When a user reports a 'something went wrong' error with a quote or bug, follow these steps: 1) Confirm the user is using the Google Chrome browser. 2) Ensure the user has a strong Wi-Fi connection. 3) If the issue persists after these checks, escalate the case to a support agent.
input: Hi im from georgia there is a bug in the website I get a 404 on my chrome and my wifi works great on other sites. can you fix it?
expected_answer: Thanks for confirming you‚Äôre using Chrome and that your Wi-Fi connection is working well. Since the issue is still happening after those checks, I‚Äôll escalate this case to a support agent so they can investigate and help resolve it.

instruction: Baggage and Personal Effects coverage provides reimbursement for personal items lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip, including while items are checked with a common carrier. It may also cover reimbursement for replacing a passport, visa, or credit card, as well as purchases made if your baggage is delayed for 12 hours or more.

Hi there! I'd be happy to explain what Baggage and Personal Effects coverage includes for you.

This coverage provides reimbursement for personal items that are lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed during a covered trip ‚Äî including items you've checked with a common carrier like an airline.

‚Ä¢ **Passport, visa, or credit card replacement** ‚Äî if these need to be replaced during your trip

So whether it's your luggage going missing or needing to replace important travel documents, this coverage has you covered. üòä Do you have any other questions about what's included?

3. Passport, visa, or credit card replacement coverage ‚úì

The agent's answer is more detailed and user-friendly than the expected answer, which is acceptable per the evaluation criteria. instruction: When answering questions about the government shutdown, clearly state that the policy does not cover incidents related to the shutdown if the event was known at the time of purchase. For policies purchased after October 1, incidents related to the government shutdown are not covered, as the shutdown became a known event on October 1.
input: Hi, I'm from CO. I'm worried the government shutdown might delay my trip. If I buy a policy now, will I be covered for issues caused by the shutdown?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. The government shutdown became a known event on October 1, so any policies purchased after that date do not provide coverage for incidents related to the shutdown. Because it‚Äôs already a known event, issues caused by it would not be covered.
agent_answer:
Thanks for reaching out! I totally understand your concern about your upcoming trip ‚Äì travel disruptions can definitely be stressful.

Here's what you need to know about coverage and the government shutdown:

**All policy coverages apply to unknown events.** Since the government shutdown became a known event on October 1, policies purchased after this date may not be covered for incidents related to the government shutdown.

I know that might not be the answer you were hoping for, but I want to be upfront with you about how this works. 

If you have further questions about how this affects your specific policy, I'm happy to help clarify. Feel free to share more details about your situation, and we can explore what options might be available to you! ü§ù
reason:
The agent followed the core instruction correctly. The key requirement was to clearly state that policies purchased after October 1 do not cover incidents related to the government shutdown because it became a known event on that date. The agent output includes this essential information: "Since the government shutdown became a known event on October 1, policies purchased after this date may not be covered for incidents related to the government shutdown."

While the agent's tone is more conversational and empathetic than the expected answer, and includes additional helpful language (acknowledging the user's concern, offering further assistance, exploring options), the core logic and the critical information match the expected answer. The agent clearly communicates the cutoff date (October 1), explains why coverage doesn't apply (known event), and specifies which policies are affected (those purchased after October 1).

The differences in presentation (tone, additional context, emoji) do not go against the instruction and are acceptable variations in communication style.

instruction: You cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. Additionally, you cannot purchase a second plan on trip once the first plan ends to extend coverage, all policies must be purchased prior to the start of the trip.
input: Hi, I'm from CA. My trip already started but I want to extend my coverage by a few more days. Can you extend my current plan?
expected_answer: Thanks for reaching out. Coverage cannot be extended once your trip has already started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased before your trip begins, up until departure.
agent_answer:
I appreciate you reaching out, and I completely understand wanting to extend your coverage while you're traveling! Unfortunately, I have some important information to share with you.

With Faye travel insurance, coverage extensions aren't available once your trip has already started. All Faye travel insurance plans must be purchased before your trip begins, up until your departure date. Additionally, you won't be able to purchase a second plan after your first one ends to extend your coverage either‚Äîall policies need to be in place prior to the start of your trip.

I know this might not be the answer you were hoping for, and I'm sorry we can't help extend your current plan. If you have any other questions about your existing coverage or how Faye policies work, I'm here to help! üòä
reason:
The agent's output follows the core instruction and conveys the essential message of the expected answer. While the tone is more conversational and empathetic (different from the expected answer's more direct approach), the critical information is all present and accurate:

1. Coverage cannot be extended once the trip has started ‚úì
2. Faye travel insurance must be purchased before the trip begins, up until departure ‚úì
3. Cannot purchase a second plan after the first one ends to extend coverage ‚úì
4. All policies must be purchased prior to trip start ‚úì

The agent provides additional context and emotional support without contradicting the instruction. The core logic and message are aligned with the expected answer, just delivered with more detail and warmth. This falls under the "When To Pass" criteria where the agent answer has more information than expected but the core logic is close enough.

instruction: You cannot extend your coverage once your trip has started. Faye travel insurance must be purchased prior to your trip, up until departure. Additionally, you cannot purchase a second plan on trip once the first plan ends to extend coverage, all policies must be purchased prior to the start of the trip.
input: Hi, I'm from NV. My policy ends tomorrow but I‚Äôm still traveling. Can I buy another plan right now to keep myself covered for a few more days?
expected_answer: Thanks for checking in. You can‚Äôt purchase a second plan to extend coverage once your trip has already begun. All policies must be purchased before the start of your trip, so we‚Äôre unable to extend or restart coverage mid-trip.
agent_answer:
I completely understand your concern about staying protected while you're still traveling ‚Äì that's really important! Unfortunately, I have to share that you won't be able to extend your coverage once your trip has started. Here's what this means for your situation:

**Coverage timing with Faye travel insurance:**
- All policies must be purchased **before your trip starts**, up until your departure date
- You can't purchase a second plan once your first plan ends to extend coverage for the remainder of your trip

I know this might be frustrating to hear, especially since your policy ends tomorrow and you're still away. The key takeaway is that Faye travel insurance needs to be set up before you leave home ‚Äì it's not something that can be added or extended once you're already traveling.

If you have any questions about this or want to discuss your options, I'm here to help! üòä

The agent's answer includes additional helpful context (acknowledging the customer's frustration, offering further assistance) which doesn't contradict the instruction - it simply provides a more comprehensive response. The core instruction is fully respected and communicated clearly.

instruction: When available, rental car coverage must be added as an optional benefit during plan selection.
